chapter.title: The Flow editor tab
chapter.para: To create a Flow, the user can follow the instructions of .

tip.para: Instead of buttons from the toolbar, try using context menus. To do so, right-click on a program that has been already added. The user can notice that many commands can be accessed through this menu. For certain cases, this method is easier and faster than using command buttons.

section.title: Assembling the Flow
section.para: In GÃªBR, a Flow is a sequence of operations defined by the user. These operations, also called Flow's programsProgram, are organized into the following categories according to their purpose:

listitem.para: Gain, NMO, Stack and Standard Processes

section.para: To create a Flow, the user must select and order programs from the above categories. Now, the user can see how this is done:

step.para: In the tab Projects and Lines, check that a Line has been selected.

Now click on the tab Flows, then left-click on
.

The dialog box Flow "New Flow" Properties will appear. The user must fill in a title for this Flow (for example, My First Flow). The user can also give a brief description of the Flow, the author and an e-mail for contact. If the user is done filling in this Flows properties click on OK.
Now the user has to select the tab Flow Editor. On the right side a list with several menus will be shown . Choose one of them and include it in the Flow with a double-click.
If the user needs a specific order to the selected programs of the flow, he or she just needs to drag and drop the desired programs.

mediaobject.caption: In the Flow Editor tab, the user will see the MenusMenu bo, on the right side of the main window. From this box the user can add programs to the Flow, which will appear in the Flow sequence box on the left side of the main window.

step.para:
To enable a program of the Flow, the user has to right-click over it and select the Configured option. The icon will change from
to
.

mediaobject.caption: To enable a program, select the Configured option.

tip.para:
If the user wants to change all programs, or a few, to the configured state simultaneously, he or she can select them by using
Ctrl Click . Then right-click on one of the selected programs, choose the option Configured from the menu that appeared. All the programs that were selected will be altered to the state
.

important.para:
To run a Flow all the programs listed in the Flow Sequence box must be Configured (
). Otherwise the Flow will not be executed as expected.

The state of a Flow, or a set of Flows, can be changed by using the hotkey Spacebar, which alters the state of the selected programs in the order Not configured, Disabled and Configured. The meaning of these states will be further described later on.

section.para:
The Flow is ready to be executed. Click on
to do it.

After the Flow has been, it will be visible on the left side of the main window when the Flows tab is selected. The Details box, found on the right side of the main window, shows information about the selected Flow .
section.tip: There is no limit on the number of Flows that can be created inside a Line.

tip.para: The user can alter the position of the Flow in the list by dragging the Flow with the mouse to the desired position.
The information bar just bellow the menu Actions shows the complete Flow tree of the selected Flow.

section.title: Copying, pasting and deleting programs
section.para:
In the same manner the user can copy and paste Flows (see ), a program (or set of programs) can be copied to the clipboard by clicking
or by using the shortcut
Ctrl C .

To remove a program (or set of programs), select them and click on
.

tip.para:
The user can deal with several programs at once by holding
Ctrl Click or
Shift Click .

A program (or set of programs) that have been copied to the clipboard can be pasted on any Flow, and not just the Flow of origin. The user can simply switch to the Flows tab, select the target Flow, go back to the Flow Editor tab and paste the program(s).

caution.para: GÃªBR does not ask for confirmation before deleting programs from a Flow.

section.title: Editing program's parameters
section.para: Program's parameters compose a set of initial configurations defined by the user.
To edit program's parameters the user must follow the steps below:

step.para:
Select the program from the Flow sequence box and click on
on the toolbar, or just double-click on the program. The Parameter dialog box will appear.
Edit the program's parameters. Notice that each program's parameter vary greatly both in size and type.

tip.para: The user can click on the Help button (bottom left corner of the dialog box) to view the program's documentation. This will be certainly useful when the user is editing the programs parameters.
The user can click on the Default button when he or she wants the program to return to its default configurations.

step.para: When the user is done, he or she has to click on the OK button.

section.title: Changing a program's state
section.para:
After the user has carried out process of , the icon beside the program will change from
to
. This means that the program's state passed from Not configured to the Configured state. Besides these two states, the program can also be set to the Disabled state (
). The user can alternate between these states by using two methods: right-clicking on the program and then select the desired state from the context menu or using the shortcut
Spacebar to change the state(s) of the selected programs.

tip.para:
The user can select several programs whose state is desired to change by holding
Ctrl Click or
Shift Click .
Changing a program state does not alter its parameter configuration. The user can safely alternate between states.

important.para:
Disabled programs (
) will be ignored when the Flow runs. This way, the user can enable and disable parts of the Flow.

section.title: Editing the Flow's input and output files
section.para: To associate an input, output and error file to a Flow, the user must follow this steps:

mediaobject.caption: Select the Flow Editor Tab. In the Flow sequence box the user can edit the input, output and log files for this Flow sequence.

step.para: Select a Flow, in the Flow tab, and switch to the Flow Editor tab.
In the Flow sequence box, the user can edit the input, output and log files paths by double clicking on them.

section.para: If the user wants to use the folders associated to the Line, he or she can either choose like above or the user can use the feature of autocomplete of the important folders of this Line.

mediaobject.caption: Autocomplete feature in the Input file of a Flow.

section.para:
When the user chooses a path for the Flow's input/output, their file paths will appear in the Flow sequence box, indicated by the icons
and
, below and above the Flow's programs (if there are any).

note.para: If the user wishes to remove a set from the list, select them by pressing right-click and then click on Exclude.

section.title: Executing a Flow
section.para:
To execute the current Flow, the user has to click on
or use the Flows tab (check ).

In the Flow Editor Tab, the user can execute a Flow after another Flow, creating a queue of execution. To execute after a specific Flow, instead of executing "Immediately", the user can switch to the Flow Editor Tab and choose the "After Flow A".
By default, the Flows are executed on the Maestro group. More details about the definition and selection of servers and groups of servers can be found in .

In the Flow Editor tab, even if the user has selected several Flows from the Flows tab, when he/she clicks on
, only the first of the selected Flows will be executed.

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of the Flow Editor tab. In the first menu of the Run, the user can choose after which flow it will be executed.

section.para: At the moment the Flow is executed, GÃªBR automatically switches to the Job Control tab and displays a report of the execution of the Flow .

section.title: Executing a Flow multiple times
section.para: The program LoopLoop (from the category Loops) has a totally different usage compared to the remaining programs from GÃªBR. The user is going to see some of these differences.

When the user adds the program Loop, it always appears on the top of the Flow. That happens to indicate that the Flow is going to be executed more than once, according to the parameters set for the program. (see for further details).

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of program Loop, added to a Flow and properly configured.

section.para: After the Loop is added, the user has access to a new variable, the iter (see ). The value of this special variable is modified on each iteration (increasing or decrementing), according to the parameters set.

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of the edition from parameters of Loop program, with a simple example of parameters setting.

section.title: Multiple machines
section.para: If GÃªBR is connected to multiple machines through the Servers Configuration interface, and the selected Flow is parallelizableFlowparallelizable (see below the criteria to be parallelizable), then you have the option to run it in a distributed way.
To be considered parallelizable, besides having a loop, a Flow must achieve one of these criteria:

listitem.para: The Flow does not have an output file or, if it has one, the output has to depend on the variable iter;
The output of each step of the loop is not the input of any other step of the loop.

section.para: In case the Flow is not parallelizable (i.e., does not fit one of the above conditions), GÃªBR will run the job in the best machine at the time of execution (GÃªBR rank them based mainly in availability and speed). In a distributed execution, it may be important to differentiate the Priority mode. When the Flow is parallelizable, it is splitted up and distributed between the available machines according to their ranking.
If the user wants to run a Flow in a specific machine, then he can force the execution by going to Flow Editor tab, as choosing the working machine as shown below.
